title: 7 Steps to Quietly Exit a System That Wants You Dependent
summary: A foundational guide to reclaiming sovereignty system-by-system. Each step offers a small, doable action that helps you become less dependent on centralized structures and more aligned with resilient, community-rooted alternatives.

Food.summary: Reclaim your autonomy by growing, preserving, and sharing food.

resources.label: National Center for Home Food Preservation

level0: Replace one grocery item with something homegrown or traded
level1: Join or start a garden trade network
Start a compost pile or worm bin
level2: Preserve a seasonal harvest for winter
level3: Convert lawn to productive growing space

Power.summary: Build resilience through small-scale backups and off-grid cooking.

level0: Buy a battery pack or small backup power station
Cook one meal without electricity (solar oven, camp stove, etc.)
level1: Install a solar charger for devices
level2: Switch to a green energy provider
level3: Design a partial solar system for your home
Run a critical load panel for essential circuits

Money.summary: Redefine security as access, not accumulation.

level0: Track monthly expenses and reduce fixed costs
level1: Barter for goods or services with neighbors
Create a wishlist of tools to share or co-own
level2: Host a barter night or resource swap
Build a shared tool lending spreadsheet
level3: Launch a formal neighborhood barter system
Prototype a local mutual credit model

Community.summary: Mutual support is infrastructure—start building it now.

level0: Ask a friend to join you in this journey
level1: Start a text thread for your street
Host a small gathering or resilience dinner
level2: Start a tool-sharing group using NeighborhoodShare
level3: Coordinate with others to map your block’s strengths and needs

Communication.summary: Choose tools that serve you—not those that track you.

level0: Switch to Signal for secure messaging
Try Brave or DuckDuckGo for private browsing
level1: Start using email aliasing (e.g., via Proton)
Audit app permissions and revoke excess access
level2: Help a friend or family member make one privacy switch
Build a personal toolkit for offline comms
level3: Prototype a local mesh network or SMS alert system
Create a guide or workshop for digital offboarding

Knowledge.summary: Learn enough to act. Teach enough to multiply impact.

level0: Watch one tutorial video for a new skill
Ask a neighbor or elder to show you something they know
level1: Teach someone else a skill you’ve gained
Join or start a local learning circle
level2: Document your offramp progress in a shared folder or blog
level3: Build a local skill school or maker co-op
Start a podcast or publication documenting your community’s wisdom

level0: Talk about offramping with a friend or family member
Post one story of progress or hope publicly
level1: Write or record a piece about your motivation to change
Host a ‘resilience movie night’ or storytelling circle
level2: Run a campaign highlighting local offramp successes
Design posters, memes, or flyers for awareness
level3: Build a local media channel or zine
Launch a storytelling or documentary project for your area
